If an eligible employer elects, within 180 days after the enactment of this Act, to spin off liability, the applicable pension plan's assets and liabilities will be transferred to an eligible spunoff plan. The employer's liability will then be determined under subsection (b) if the election is made, or under subsection (c) if no election is made. Days after enactment, the applicable pension plan must spin off assets and liabilities to an eligible plan. The employer's liability will be determined by the eligible spunoff plan instead of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The employer's liability for the applicable pension plan shall be determined by the eligible spunoff plan instead of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The amendments made by the Pension Protection Act of 2006 will not apply until the plan ceases to be an eligible spunoff plan. The employer maintaining the plan is liable for ongoing contributions to the eligible spunoff plan on the same terms as under ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code, in lieu of any other liability to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The employer maintaining the plan is liable for ongoing contributions to the eligible spunoff plan on the same terms as under ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code. This liability is in lieu of any other liability to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the applicable pension plan. Interest rates are determined based on specific sections of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Security Act of 1974 and Internal Revenue Code of 1986 determine interest rates for ongoing contributions to eligible spunoff plans. The third segment rate is applied for plan years before amendments made by the Pension Protection Act of 2006. The third segment rate is used for plan years before amendments by the Pension Protection Act of 2006. If an eligible spunoff plan terminates before December 31, 2010, the employer's liability is determined according to specific methods. The liability of the employer for maintaining a terminated pension plan under section 4062 of ERISA is determined based on specific assumptions and methods. This liability is in lieu of any other obligations to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the pension plan. If an eligible employer does not elect a spinoff, they will be liable to the corporation for the terminated plan under ERISA. If an eligible employer does not elect a spinoff for a terminated pension plan under ERISA, they will be liable to the corporation for the plan's unfunded benefit liabilities as of December 31, 2005. The adjusted unfunded benefit liabilities of a pension plan must be paid to the corporation if an eligible employer does not elect a spinoff for the plan. The liabilities are based on the amount of unfunded benefit liabilities as of December 31, 2005, with specific interest assumptions. The term "fractional portion" refers to a fraction representing the employer's contributions to a pension plan for the 5 plan years before December 31, 2005, compared to the total required contributions. The term "fractional portion" is defined as a fraction representing the employer's contributions to an applicable pension plan for the 5 plan years before December 31, 2005, compared to the total required contributions from all employers not making a specific election. Additionally, an "applicable pension plan" is a single employer plan established in Alaska on March 18, 1967, with 2 or more contributing sponsors, at least 2 of which are not under common control as of January 1, 2005. The term "applicable pension plan" refers to a single employer plan established in Alaska on March 18, 1967, with 2 or more contributing sponsors, at least 2 of which are not under common control as of January 1, 2005. The "allocable portion" is the portion of the plan's liabilities and assets that corresponds to an eligible employer's share of the excess liabilities of the plan. An eligible employer in an eligible multiple employer plan is defined as an employer participating in the plan after January 1, 2000. The employer's share of the plan's excess liabilities is determined based on the ratio of the employer's liabilities to assets compared to the total excess amount.
